First off, I want to say that I am sick about all the people bashing Helen Hunt's appearance. I thought this was the age of anti-internet bullying. Just because someone has had work done, does not give any of us the license to be cruel about their appearance. If you know her personally, are in her line of work, or are a qualified doctor, contact her or her agent and have a conversation. Or, if you're someone who, if you were in her position, would enjoy having the same kinds of things said about you, criticize on.Now, about the movie. It started out like a paranormal thriller, and paranormal things make me giggle. I was giggling the first 20 minutes. Then everything switched, and it became a different genre all together, and I was into it. The ending of any story will make or break it. The ending of this story made it. After watching and thinking about it, all I can say it is a tight, clever story. Well worth the watch.

It's clear to me that the people who gave this flick high scores either worked on the film or know someone who did. Or, they got paid to leave good reviews.I have loved Helen Hunt's work since childhood when she used to play mean, snobby, little jerks, through all of her adult roles, so I was terribly disappointed to feel like I'd been betrayed by a lifelong friend. I know it's not altogether her fault, if at all. I just found all of the acting to feel detached, uninhabited. Actors acting. Not once did I feel swept up in the story, except perhaps when Libe Barer was in the scene. She was exquisitely believable as a teenage girl thrilled by phrogging. There was no depth to any of the other characters. Is that the actors' faults, or the director's?The only even barely redeeming quality to the movie was a plot twist about halfway through when it was made clear that the character you assumed did the bad thing was revealed to not have done it, when you learn who did. But that is it. All the other potentially interesting story lines were so watered down as to make it a film of barely-there stories, each one separated from the other, brought together in a mishmash concoction that had no grip to it. I was grateful when it was finally over.The long slow shots had me hitting the fast forward button more than once, partly due to the sound design which seemed overwhelmingly creepy on shots that otherwise would just be a suburban house or living room.I'll refrain from expounding very greatly on my disappointment at seeing that Ms Hunt has fallen into the celebrity trap of plastic surgery. There IS beauty in the natural order of things, and I hope one day soon our society will accept women over 40, 50 & up for the exquisite grace that comes with years. Think Katherine Hepburn, Charlotte Rampling, Vanessa Redgrave. It makes me grateful to be of modest means so as to avoid the temptation.

While this second pass explains the odd things that were happening the first time the story is told, it does start to feel a bit long and repetitive (even though the audience is getting knew information from the different point-of-view).Overall, though, there's plenty of twists that you'll never see coming (mixed in with a few giant cliches that you knew were bound to happen from the beginning). Review title: Hand held shaky camera movie is a mega bore
Review_body: I was fortunate enough to be brought up on great movies. Well made, well acted. Movies with award-winning photography, acting and stories.But having read some of the glowing review for I see You, I realise there is a generation of movie goers who do not have the same standards as me and others.What is wrong with I see You? Well the fact it only cost $3 million tells you something. Tells you a lot. Tells you they couldn't be bothered to make a decent movie. They went for the hand held shaky camera option which I have to say I hate. I hate it in horror movies and I hate it in thrillers. It's lazy, boring and very irritating.Someone said I had to see I See You, 'it's great'. Oh no it's awful. Badly acted, a boring story but worst of all is there are no proper scenes. We're meant to believe people spend their lives walking around with a camcorder recording everything. You know why they did that, because the director couldn't be bothered to set up the scenes properly. Couldn't be bothered with the lighting, camera angles, etc. Nothing. In fact the lighting in this movie is terrible.I also couldn't finish the movie. It got me so annoyed I stopped watching 45 minutes in.Garbage from start to finish. Cheap and lazy. 1/10.

I'm one of those people who most often pushes through a book I'm not enjoying for two reasons: first, I figure, this thing has been accepted for publication, has made it through editorial, has actually been published, and is popular. If I'm hating it, must be my fault. Second, It's the old story of throwing good money after bad. I keep hoping things will turn around. Now, after having spent almost two hours on this movie for those same reasons, I'm left with the same feeling I get when I've missed the parking meter by five minutes and there's a ticket on my windshield.My objections and questions:
1. I think it's finally occurred to me that I like Helen Hunt better as a person (although I don't know her) than as an actress. Even in the Mad About You days, it was Paul Reiser who drove the comedy. She was the beautiful foil. I know that it lacks a kind of fairness, especially in these times, to talk about a woman's face, but an actor's face is one of his/her principle tools, so I'll plow ahead. I don't know if Helen Hunt has had any work done (no criticism if she has; I'm a fan of cosmetic surgery done well if that's what a person wants to do), but in I See You, her face looks so smooth and taut that very little in the way of emotions register. This isn't helped by her often wooden delivery of her lines. I get that she's forcing herself to try to be cheerful and normal in order to try to to reach her angry son, but it's not only in those scenes. I never believe her character. I'm always saying to myself, "That's Helen Hunt acting." Also, not her fault, but how about a little makeup? Get those deep set eyes out of her brow a bit.
2. One of the very first things we see is 10-year-old Justin getting kidnapped in the woods. But not just getting mugged and pulled into a car. Flying, flying up into the air backwards, a clear sign to me that this is an alien abduction at least. Reinforcing that premise is the abundance of drone shots, suggesting that there are supernatural forces at work. But then, at the end, nothing about that. It's just a garden variety human serial killer/kidnapper. So was that flying supposed to be? A metaphor? Sorry. Not fair.
3. I won't even touch the whole parallel plot of Phrogging, which explains so many of the mysterious events going on in the house (the missing mug, the mug that not only falls down off the roof, but arcs out at just the right angle to hit Tommy in the head, the missing flatware, the missing photos, Greg getting locked in the closet, and the music on the turntable). I mean, aside from the fact that, on some level, they all sort of accept these very spooky events in a way (blame them on Connor's bad mood?), well, okay, pretty dubious, but you would think they'd want to spend a little more time and energy unpacking these things even if it's by interrogating Connor. Greg is a detective, after all.
4. The music is heavy, ominous, spooky, and terrific. Just not for this movie.Now onto the mess of the climax and the ending:
5. a. Greg was kidnapping kids into a trailer in the woods, to do what? When is he there? What is he feeding them? Where are they going to the bathroom? What are his intentions?
b. Are we supposed to believe that Greg is a copycat criminal or that the person in jail for the Swiss Army knife crimes has been framed by Greg? His partner, an African-American cop with an unlikely German last name (Spitzky-okay, possible, but why?) wanders around in bewilderment. That's fine, Spitzky, you're right: it doesn't make any sense.
c. Was that a bag of green Swisss Army knives in the trailer? Aside from psychotic criminals in cat-and-mouse crime movies, the closest I come to understanding why Greg is leaving these knives around is Marv from Home Alone, turning on the faucets of the houses he robs so he and Harry will be known as the Wet Bandits. Just stupid.
d. I admit I may have missed a detail, but once it's discovered, at the house, that Greg is the bad guy, how do the police find out there's a trailer in the woods and where it is? Who knows the way? Greg can't tell them; Alec killed him. And again, how are those two kids alive and pretty well?
e. And Jackie's reaction: pretty much nothing. Shock? Maybe, but I'd have preferred a little hysteria here.6. And now, the part that makes the least sense of all: Tommy and Jackie were high school sweethearts. By now, they have to be in their forties, right? Alec, the Pfrogger, is a teenager. Or maybe he's supposed to be a college student. Give him early twenties, even though it's a stretch. Yet, at the end, the two of them are walking along the train track as children, approximately the same age, buddies, when they encounter Greg, who looks like he's offering them a green Swiss Army knife. Wha'? I mean, the close-up of young Alec, pre-orthodontia, cutting up and back with the close-up of present-day Alec on the gurney, that's supposed to let us know that it's Alec, no? So, the ridiculous anachronism aside, does Alex recognize Greg when he's still in the house? Or, oh no, is the train track scene supposed to be another metaphor?I just don't understand the number of good reviews this film has gotten. I think it's a package of tropes that doesn't hang together.

I thought it was going to be a paranormal premise and I was a little disappointed about that but then events were explained and it turned out that the cause of everything could be attributed to normal, everyday occurrences and actions by normal, everyday people. I may be naive, but I just like to be entertained. So, when seemingly "good" people end up being the villain and then the villain is good again- I'm not mad or confused, I'm surprised and entertained! I thought it all meshed well and the ending wrapped things up fairly well but I would've like more explanation about "why???" But, there are those viewers who like to be left to fill in the blanks. All in all- you won't be wasting 2 hours of your time :)

Review title: Great story but could have been tightened up a little
Review_body:
It's not easy to review this film without giving too much away, as there is a twist in the tale.
It is part murder mystery and part family drama with some points teasing at supernatural goings-on.
We have a couple trying to get through a recent affair and their teenage son reacting very negatively. This gets overshadowed by some unusual occurrences in the house and a recent spate of missing children, which is being investigated by our poor cheated-on husband.
The film shifts entirely halfway through and we start seeing the story from another perspective.
Though the twist and the execution are very clever, the second half needs trimming. We are shown things that are somewhat unnecessary and the set-up for this act is a little long.
What could have been a great film is just a good one because of the overly long reveals at the end.
Personally I think this should have made it into the theaters over many others

Review title: Excellent Storytelling in a Slow and Deliberate Unfolding
Review_body: This is a well-told story that slowly unfolds with an unconventional timeline. It may seem a little slow, for some, in the beginning, but stick with it. The pace is purposeful. The bad reviews seem to come from people who are more interested in simple blood and gore horror. This is horror, too... but it is also, suspense, mystery, and thriller. It was obvious from the beginning that the viewer would be exposed to multiple storylines, but the deliberate layering pays off later with a reveal most won't see coming.
